speaker: Mr Brough (Longman) (5.57 P.m.)
theText: I introduced into this parliament a piece ofWe support employers because they, in House adjourned at 6 p.m. tum, support employees. That is of importance to the Australian economy if it is to PAPERS grow. Those opposite have also made lots The following papers were deemed to have over the last couple of days about commitbeen presented on 23 May 1996: ments. March2 was not that long ago and, in Veterans' Entitlements Act-Intruments under that short period, the Prime Minister( Mr section 196B 1996 Nos. 67, 68, 69, 70, 71, 72, 73, Howard) has already74, 75, 76, 77, 78, 79, 80, 81, 82. Thursday, 23 May 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1323 Thursday, 23 May 1996 . BILL 1996 Second Reading Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Dr Kemp: That the bill be now read a second time. bill, which will provide an additional $95.7 million to improve Aboriginal educational opportunities. I am especially pleased because this bill is the result of an initiative of the federal Labor government. In setting up the national review of education for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in 1993, the former government was recognising the fact, stated in the 1994-95 report Social justice for indigenous Australians, that Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islander people were 'the poorest, sickest, most unemployed and least educated of all Australians'. The review was established to examine the operation of the first triennium of the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy, AEP. The AEP began in 1990 as a national effort between the Commonwealth, the states and territories and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to strategically address the educational needs of indigenous Australians. The AEP identified 21 goals under four main themes: involvement, access, participation and outcomes; particularly recognising the fundamental importance of the involvement of indigenous people at all stages of decision making. The original joint policy statement of the AEP in 1989 acknowledged the power of education to improve the quality of life for people from financially impoverished backgrounds. The joint policy statement says: Numerous reviews, inquiries and consultations conducted in recent years have all demonstrated that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people place a high priority on education. They want for themselves and their children no less by way of educational opportunity than is afforded other Australians. They expect that educational processes should leave them to acquire the knowledge and skills necessary to realise their individual potential, lead satisfying lives and contribute actively to the community. They look to education as a means of moving out of poverty and welfare dependency, enabling them to earn income through employment or enterprise and to manage the development of their communities. Five years after the AEP was established was a suitable time to consider the extent to which it had met expectations in terms of the 21 goals. The review praised the AEP for delivering more funding stability in the form of triennial rather than annual arrangements, for fostering cooperation between federal, territory and state governments and between education sectors, and for identifying the need for more culturally appropriate curricula. Not surprisingly, it also found that the AEP's first three years held some lessons for its future operation. In terms of educational participation and attainment, the review found that improvements, although evident, were inconsistent across sectors and systems. It found that many parents now have an avenue for becoming directly involved in their children's schooling through the establishment of over 2,500 parent committees under the Aboriginal student
title: Conclusion

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Nebl) Took The Chair At 10.00 A.m.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Peter Baldwin (Sydney) (10.01 A.m.)
theText: -I am delighted to speak in support of thisMC 1324 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 23 May 1996 support and parent awareness program, ASSPA. It also found that the cooperative national approach of the AEP had encouraged the development of Aboriginal studies and Torres Strait Islander studies as part of the curriculum in an increasing number of educational institutions. These kinds of improvements were not seen uniformly across the country, however, and addressed to only a limited extent the extreme educational disadvantage facing our indigenous population. The review made 44 recommendations designed to improve Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people's experience of education. Sixteen of the recommendations apply specifically to the Commonwealth, while others involve the state and territory governments and non-government education authorities. The former government responded to the review in September last year, announcing a package of measures which included those incorporated in this bill. The response announced the Labor government's intention to make the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program recurrent, and this measure is a key part of the bill we are considering today. It will provide greater stability of funding, as well as ensuring that funds remain commensurate with enrolments. It will also simplify funding arrangements, addressing complaints made to the review about the time spent preparing submissions. In line with review recommendation 37, the proposal is to provide funds on a per capita basis and in a way which reflects the differing costs of educational provision across sectors, and in remote and nonremote areas. I note that the government intends these changes to accompany a more accountable outcomes-focused process for the distribution of Commonwealth funds. There is no doubt that we need to continue down the path set by the previous government in placing a high priority on establishing comprehensive and up-to-date databases across all sectors of education and training so that the performance of the AEP in meeting its objectives can be properly evaluated. The previous government also obtained agreement from most states to increase their effort in Aboriginal education expenditure in order to access a pool of Commonwealth money in the form of strategic results projects. The opposition will be most interested in arrangements made with the states as a result of this bill. We would expect the government to ensure that commitments made by the states to increase effort are not permitted to lapse due to any reduction in commitment by the Commonwealth or any diminution of resolve on the part of the Commonwealth. There is far too much at stake. In closing, I would like to congratulate the chair of the reference group overseeing the review, Mandawuy Yunupingu; the deputy chair, Romina Fujii; and the other members of the reference group on the excellent job they did. I would also like to say that real improvements can be made in indigenous education if all governments work together with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. We have come some of the way; this bill takes us further toward our goal. have taken a personal interest for some years. I am therefore very pleased to speak on this particular bill this morning. One of the things that has struck me over the six years I have been in this place is that not only here but also as I have travelled around the country-with you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and with other members on the standing committee and through other outlets and avenues-I have heard many claims from different people about what the keys are to addressing Aboriginal
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Nugent (Aston) (10.08 A.m.)
theText: As this House will know, this is an area in which IThursday, 23 May 1996 MAIN COMMITfEE Me 1325 and Torres Strait Islander disadvantage in this country. And there is acknowledged and quite clear disadvantage, by whatever indicator you care to use. When people talk about the key to addressing that disadvantage, they sometimes talk about health; they sometimes talk about housing, education, employment, the importance of land, the justice system, and so on. It seems to me that those things are all important. It is not just one of those items being the key; they all play an important part and it seems to me that it should be an interactive process. You have to improve housing and health in parallel with education and gradually develop that total environment. I know the next honourable gentleman to speak from the coalition-he comes from the Northern Territory and we welcome him to this parliament-will probably have more first-hand experience of this than I, but I have certainly travelled extensively around the country. What we have seen and heard as we go around the country, in terms of health and the delivery of educational services to indigenous people, has been generally a very sorry tale. You do not get a good education if your health is not up to scratch. If you have a middle ear infection-and in some schools that you and I have been to, Mr Deputy Speaker, 50 per cent of those in the school have middle ear infections-you have a health problem. But you have also got an education problem because you cannot hear what the heck is going on. So we need to look at education in the Aboriginal field in a broad sense. We also need to look at overcrowded housing. I have seen overcrowded indigenous housing all around this country. I remember particularly going to Maningrida, which is well known for its arts and crafts, where the average number of people per house in that community is about 38. If you are going to school during the day and you want to advance yourself and do some study or whatever, going home to 38 people in a three-bedroom house with one toilet and a shower, in a warm climate, is not exactly conducive to becoming a diligent student, even if you want to. The aspect of culture is interesting. AgainI would be interested in the comments, perhaps later on, from the honourable gentleman from the Northern Territory. I remember going tYirrkala which is often held up as a model school in terms of indigenous involvement in running its own education process. It is a school at which Mandawuy Yunupingu, to whom the previous speaker referred, was a teacher some years ago before he moved on to greater fame in other fields. There was great pride, and appropriately so in many senses, that the teaching was conducted in the local language. That was culturally appropriate and was acceptable to the community, but if you went down the road and talked to the major employer in the area, which was Nabalco, the management there said, 'One of the problems we have with trying to offer jobs to Aboriginal people is that, although they go to school and they go through the school system, because they often do not have a basic command of English to the standard we need we actually cannot employ them.' So you have this dichotomy of culture and education, and you have to get that mix right. Similarly, in the home environment the problem is not just the crowding. If there is substance abuse at home and there is violence or other problems of that sort, clearly you are not going to sit down and do your homework and have the right environment in which to study. Those sorts of problems, coupled with peer pressure and so on, I think are often worse for our indigenous community than for people almost anywhere else in the country. I specifically address my comments to the parliamentary secretary, who is here representing the minister. The point I would make is. that we can talk about these education bills, but what MC 1326 MAIN COMMITIEE Thursday, 23 May 1996 the government has to understand and what the government must do-I said this in opposition and I will continue to say it in government-is address all of these issues because addressing just particular sectional areas is not going to fix the problem. This bill is about increasing funding until the tum of the century and restructuring the Aboriginal special programs in this area to make them more responsive. This bill is about moving primarily, in one sense, to a per capita system. It is about looking for who can best provide education. I think that is important. Often the providers may not be from the conventional sources. I think that is a more relevant factor in indigenous areas than perhaps in many other parts of the community. It is particularly about looking for outcomes and not just inputs. I have been critical of many of the things the previous government did in this and other areas but I never basically questioned its good intentions. One of the things that struck me in the life of the previous government and that caused me concern was that we did not get the improved results. I think there was too much focus on providing the inputs and not enough on saying, 'Has it been effective and have we got the right results?' SoI think that looking at outcomes is fundamental. This bill is about providing certainty for the education providers, not living year to year on short-term time frames, because you cannot organise anything properly on that basis. It is about performance and outcomes, and it has also established quite clearly an objective to achieve educational equity for indigenous Australians by the tum of the century. It is about improving the lot of indigenous teachers as well. I am not sure, Mr Deputy Speaker, whether you were on this particular visit, but I have graphic memories of one visit we paid to a school which I think was in Mission Beach in Queensland where outstanding Aboriginal teachers really were teachers' aides, if you like, and had nowhere to go. There was no advancement and the level of pay was derisory. Anybody who had real ability in the Aboriginal teaching field was often lost to the field because they went to other jobs where they could get better advancement. It seems to me that there are special needs in terms of improving the lot of indigenous teachers. Of course, it is important to make education culturally appropriate, and we need-above all, perhaps-to take a practical and not a doctrinaire approach. As members of the House would be aware, I have spent some years as the coalition's representative in opposition and now in government on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. Reconciliation is something to which the Prime Minister has reaffirmed his commitment on a number of occasions since 2 March. In that context, let me say that next week we are going to celebrate National Reconciliation Week in this building. There will be a major function on Monday at lunchtime, co-hosted by the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Beazley) and the Leader of the Democrats (Senator Kernot), and there will be a special motion moved in the House at the start of business on Monday. The reason I mention that is that you do not and will not achieve reconciliation until you have addressed many of the problems that are almost endemic in the disadvantage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians. Improving that disadvantage, it seems to me, is one of the issues at the core and that is why bills such as this are so important. I would just remind members of the House that in the second reading speech the minister said that this bill was all about funding levels that reflect an increase of $7.85 million on the existing appropriation. Thursday, 23 May 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1327 The bill is talking about major changes to the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program from January 1997 with a new funding triennium. It is talking about cultural appropriateness and a more cost-effective, transparent and manageable system, and it would do this in two basic ways: on the basis of either per capita entitlement or strategic results projects. It is all about value for money and about getting results. As I have said before, I have never doubted that the previous government wanted to try hard in this area, but I have concerns that they did not achieve outcomes, and that is why it is important that we develop a new way of going about some of these things. In doing that, we must of course remember that we need to involve Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander parents in their children's education process. You cannot just devise a system and expect that it is going to work. Given the many tight-knit communities, it is important to involve parents because without that parental commitment-and that often is not there these days-and given some of the problems of health, housing and so on that I referred to earlier, you will not get children motivated to do the work they need to at school. We need to very much improve the preschool education level because, unless you can set at an early age the right approaches, attitudes and even disciplines to education, you will get the wrong attitude set at an early age; and if a few years later you come along trying to change the attitude of the young people to education, you will not be successful. Obviously, it must be about employing and training Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education workers. There simply are not enough of them in the field and we need to encourage far more people into that area. The employment and training of those workers-acknowledging that it may have to use techniques that are not necessarily standard in terms of the main community-will be important. The appropriate professional development of staff at all levels involved in indigenous education is important, and I have mentioned the cultural sensitivity of curricula as also being important. Probably more than anything else, we have to make sure that in all the things we plan and do; in all the changes we look at and the things we implement, we have indigenous involvement in how we develop the programs, in the measures that we take and in the mechanics of the system. History. has taught us that we cannot impose those things from the outside. Unless there is indigenous involvement the measures will-in all sorts of ways-not be appropriate and there will be no commitment in the communities themselves to make them work successfully afterwards. This legislation seeks to achieve for indigenous Australians literacy and numeracy outcomes that are similar to those of non-indigenous Australians. It also seeks to make sure that we regularly review progress so that we can try to achieve the objective, or get very close to it, by 2000. I do not think we are going to bring everybody up to scratch in the next four years, but we have to make significant progress. Everybody in our community, whether an indigenous or non-indigenous person, is very frustrated with the fact that all the effort and all the talk that has gone on for some years has not produced the outcome. I am not attributing blame or pointing a finger, but we all acknowledge that the improvements are not there and, therefore, people are getting frustrated. We must start to see some impact being made on some of these areas. It is important that we give priority in that process to addressing the development of sound foundation competencies, particularly in literacy and numeracy, so that we can help Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people make the transition from education and training, where they MC 1328 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 23 May 1996 get those basic skills, into the work force. Until you have the basic skills, you will not get a job; if you do not get a job then you cannot afford the housing; and if you do not have the housing then you do not get the health standards. If you do not have a job and money, you get into substance abuse, because you have been sitting around doing nothing. This happens when you have time on your hands-we all know the cycle. So this bill is a very fundamental part of providing intervention at an early stage in that cycle. We all recognise the need in this area and it is no good standing up and making emotive speeches. That has happened over the years. There have been a lot of problems and mistakes made in the past. What we have to do now is sit down with legislation such as this and put in place some practical measures for dealing with the problem. This is one small part of the jigsaw. This is the educational piece of the jigsaw. There are other parts: health, housing and so on. We have to recognise the special circumstances of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians: not only their disadvantages but also the cultural differences, and we have to have them involved. This bill not only continues what was set in place before-and some of the special measures worked, and some of them did not work-but also improves what was there, based on experience. I think that is to be commended . .It is not a cure by itself, but it certainly helps. The thing that we must do, as a nation and as a parliament-the lead has to come from the parliament-is to put aside party political differences in these sorts of areas. Those of us who have worked in indigenous affairs over the last few years have tried to put aside a lot of those party political differences because, as a nation, we have a responsibility not to fail our citizens. In so many areas, including Aboriginal education, we have failed them in the past and it is important that we now address these problems. This bill will go some considerable way towards doing that, and I therefore commend the bill to honourable members. had the opportunity to speak in the Main Committee. The size of the committee is the size of the parliament of the Northern Territory when I first spoke in it in about 1974. Mr Ted Grace--You seem very much at home. bill, which will amend the Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act of 1989. The bill will ensure that a significant portion of funding to the states and territories, under the act, is paid on the basis of the number of indigenous students. It will also provide some extra money to Aboriginal education as approved by the Expenditure Review Committee. Poor retention rates, particularly at higher levels of secondary schooling, are a major factor in the educational disadvantage of indigenous Australians. For example, at year 12 level the retention rate is 33 per cent compared with 76 per cent for other Australians. Current funding arrangements under the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program, AESIP, are based on submissions which failed to provide certainty and continuity. Funding levels are not currently linked to outcomes and do not reflect levels of enrolment of indigenous students. The bill provides for a new approach to funding arrangements for AESIP from 1997. Most funding will now be provided through per capita based arrangements which will ensure that the bulk of the funding is predictable and based on changes in enrolment demands. An element of the available funds will also be set aside for strategic projects which will be time limited and outcomes orientated.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Dondas (Northern Territory) (10.24 A.m.)
theText: This is the first occasion on which I have
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Dondas
theText: I do feel at home, as the honourable member has said. I rise to support theThursday, 23 May 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1329 The strategic results projects wiII, in general, be jointly funded by the Commonwealth, state and territory governments. The strategic results projects wiII deal with the major barriers to educational attainment, such as the high drop-out rates, which cannot be addressed by mainstream programs. The new formula for funding recognises the different needs of various educational sectors: preschool, primary, secondary, and vocational education and training; the greater costs involved in servicing remote communities; and the needs of non-government institutions not in receipt of funding from other government channels. The biII wiII also give practical implementation to the government's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander policy commitments: to review all Commonwealth programs for indigenous students to assess their relevance and educational outcomes; to liaise with the states and territories to determine how to improve outcomes; to support in principle the 21 goals of the national review for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, while recognising that indigenous complaints voiced during the consultation phase were not necessarily reflected in the final recommendations; and to ensure that indigenous people have a greater voice in determining indigenous educational needs. Under current financial arrangements, funding is submission based. Based on the formula supplied in schedule 1, the territory would receive---on 1995 enrolments as provided under the Australian vocational education and training, or VET, statistics that include nongovernment VET providers-a decrease in funding for the vocational education and training sector. Based on these preliminary calculations, it is felt that this wiII result in a decrease in funding for the vocational education and training sector in the Northern Territory in the government and non-government sectors of some $3 miIIion per annum. Current funding arrangements have been intended to be supplementary to delivery funding. Historically, however, institutions have used the funds for delivery purposes. The impact of the per capita arrangements may affect the number of indigenous enrolments. This is clearly cost shifting, which the new formula is trying to address. Institutions wiII make claims of additional territory recurrent funds to maintain their current enrolment levels. The new funding arrangements wiII lead to a significant rearrangement in the relative shares of funds received by different states and territories. Transitional arrangements wiII ensure that the shift to per capita funding is as smooth as possible. However, these changes wiII negatively impact upon the most disadvantaged Aboriginal students in the remotest areas of Australia. While there are a number of positive aspects to this biII, the Northern Territory is greatly concerned that the level of funding available to the Northern Territory government school sector wiII decrease by 33 per cent, from approximately $10 miIIion in 1996 to $6.4 miIIion in 1997. Given that the government school sector has responsibility for providing education to 10,930 indigenous students, the large nature of this cut will have a dramatic negative impact on the programs which the department of education will be able to offer. However, two positive aspects of the bill which address the concerns of Northern Territory Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are a guaranteed funding base to provide employment and the recognition of greater delivery costs incurred in delivering educational services to remote areas. The major problem for the Northern Territory is that the main focus of the bill on improved academic outcomes will be diminished because the funding necessary to maintain programs which address improved outcomes wiII be greatly reduced. MC 1330 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 23 May 1996 The reduction in funding also places in jeopardy the implementation of the Aboriginal education strategy as agreed by the Commonwealth, state and territory ministers at the meeting of the Ministerial Council for Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs in December 1995. At that meeting, ministers agreed to continue the partnership between the Commonwealth and the states and territories, particularly to improve outcomes for indigenous students. It will be very difficult to continue the partnership when the Northern Territory government is maintaining its financial effort, only to be confronted by a reduction by the Commonwealth. Indigenous people in the Northern Territory have been asking for some time to have their jobs as Aboriginal resource officers made permanent. The Northern Territory government has always said that, as soon as the Commonwealth makes funding permanent, the Territory would make these jobs permanent. Under this new legislation, the funding will be on a recurrent basis, and therefore the Northern Territory government will be able to offer Aboriginal resource officers in urban locations permanent employment, providing the current level of the 1996 funding is maintained. Given the important role that Aboriginal resource officers play in providing support for Aboriginal students in classrooms and the example they set as role models for non-Aboriginal students, this could be another significant step in assisting with the improvement of academic outcomes for Aboriginal students and promoting a better understanding between the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Territorians. There must be a concerted effort to improve access to education and training in remote communities and to address poor health, housing and other problems that militate against educational achievement. While academic standards in Aboriginal schools are generally far below what I consider acceptable, it has to be recognised that progress is being made. With four Aboriginal principals in charge of Aboriginal schools and more in training, about 100 Aboriginal teachers and nearly 300 Aboriginal assistant teachers, we can expect the rate of improvement to increase significantly. In some isolated Aboriginal schools, the electronic classroom is already a reality, with students receiving lessons and tutorial support by computer from the Northern Territory Secondary Correspondence School. Section 10 of this bill is also very important because it acknowledges the higher costs of education delivery in remote areas, although the definition of 'remote' fails to differentiate between vastly different degrees of remoteness. I advise the honourable minister that, in terms of remote, for a primary school student the government rate isÂ· some $600 and the nongovernment rate is $2,000. In terms of remoteness, the definition is that, as I understand it, if you are more than 300 kilometres from a popUlation base of 50,000 people you come into the remote category. We provide educational services in the major regional centres of the Northern Territorywhich are Alice Springs, Tennant Creek, Katherine and Nhulunbuy-and all those Territory centres are more than 300 kilometres away from a population base of 50,000. Darwin is the only centre that has a population base of 50,000. In Alice Springs and the other Territory centres, we are funded for the remote rate per student, which is $600. At places away from those Territory centres, like Borroloola-a community some 788 kilometres from Tennant Creek or, in driving time, between eight and nine hours-education services are provided at a higher remote cost, as if it were in Alice Springs. Thursday, 23 May 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1331 With another smaller community, Kiuna-a station 580 kilometres, or six to seven hours drive, from Tennant Creek, with a population of about 35 students-if the 35 is multiplied by the $600, it finishes up at about $21,000. With the services that are being provided by the education department of the Northern Territory, a schoolteacher at that level in a remote area would probably be on about $45,000 to $50,000 a year with overtime. In other words, it is far more expensive to provide educational services to people in remote areas, which this particular per capita table will not really pick up. I would ask the minister to evaluate that in relation to the Northern Territory and other parts of the vast outback in North Queensland and Western Australia. The important thing is that, nationally, literacy levels are unacceptable and there is strong evidence that, in some remote areas, parents are more literate than their children. In fact, to pick up the points that were made by the honourable member for Aston( Mr Nugent), bilingual education is being accepted as the conventional approach, yet there is an increasing clamour from traditionally orientated communities that language maintenance is Aboriginal business and the medium of school based education ought to be English. That is really what the honourable member for Aston was saying. Obviously if peopleand their children go to school through Yirrkala, when they come out of the education system and do not speak English they cannot find work. As the member for Aston said, the mining company is unable to employ them as they do not have a decent command of the English language. We should be looking seriously now at what languages are being taught in schools because around the Northern Territory there are a number of children aged between 18 and 25 who are still somewhere in the education system and who do not have a reasonable enough command of the English language to allow them to go into the work force. So they will always be forced to stay within their community because of the dialect that they use. The introduction of this bill should have been seen as the major step in continuing the improvements of outcomes for all indigenous students in the non-government sector. There has to be great concern about the bill's availability to address the needs of indigenous students in the government school sector. The provision of a 33 per cent cut in the level of funding available to the government school sector is probably the most damaging event to occur in the history of Northern Territory Aboriginal education. This cut will directly impact on the attainment of educational outcomes at a time when more, rather than less, funding should have been devoted to this area. Accepting the fact that the former government left the new coalition government in a financial mess, I would hope that the minister responsible for this bill will recognise the important fact that not only is the Territory disadvantaged, but other states with large rural and isolated areas are also in need of special funding consideration. As this legislation is most important to the future for those persons in the indigenous education sector, I commend it to honourable members. Committee and I am looking forward to it. I am also looking forward to speaking on the Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1996 which will certainly have a very pleasing outcome for the electorate of Herbert. I want to support the bill because

title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Lindsay (Herbert) (10.38 A.m.)
theText: This is the first time. I have spoken in the MainMC 1332 MAIN COMMITIEE Thursday, 23 May 1996 every Australian has a right to expect fair and equitable access to education, but for many years indigenous Australians have, in the main, been unable to live out this right. This, unfortunately, is not unusual. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people lag well behind non-indigenous Australians in just about every social aspect of life. Health, life expectancy, employment and the representation in our gaols are just a few of the areas where indigenous Australians continue to lag well below the acceptable so-called 'average' standard of living. In education, the same can unfortunately also be said to be true. Someone once said that knowledge is power. It has been oft quoted, but I do not necessarily subscribe to this point of view. I prefer to believe that knowledge is empowerment. The difference is fundamental and the amendments presented in this bill further the quest for empowerment. The aim of this bill-to facilitate increased participation and improved education outcomes for indigenous Australians-is a positive action indeed. We can only increase participation rates for indigenous people if we improve access to educational facilities. It is important to do this from the ground up and to start at preschool and primary school. Immediately before coming here this week I officially opened the new Good Shepherd community school in Townsville. It was my first school opening and a very proud moment for me. Part of my speech called on the education department to facilitate more culturally relevant learning environments for our kids; environments which take into consideration the needs and requirements of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children and their parents. Townsville has one of the largest per capita metro-indigenous populations in Australia. It is great to see indigenous and non-indigenous children mixing so freely. That is the great thing about children. They do not carry the prejudice and racism that older people seem to carry. Getting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people involved in the educational and teaching side is an important element not only for the provision of better, more culturally relevant education programs for indigenous Australians but also for all Australians. This then needs to be carried through to secondary and tertiary levels of education. In the end, I think one of the most important educational outcomes we all hope for for our children is, of course, employment. When I was young-and I am not saying that I am not young now-an arts degree was a pretty big deal and the sign of a very well-educated person. Today an arts degree will not get a young person terribly far. Ordinary degrees are becoming double degrees with honours. I dread to think, for my own children's sake, how competitive the job market will be when they graduate from their university studies in a few years time. Not many things in politics today seem to attract bipartisan support. I think it would be a very brave member indeed who would stand up and oppose the sensible amendments proposed in this bill. I am particularly supportive of the new section 7A which defines the object of the act, which is 'to develop culturally appropriate education services for Indigenous people.' To expand on the importance of this, I want to take you to a great indigenous school in my electorate. About 40 kilometres north-east of Townsville is Palm Island. Sister Geraldine Kearney runs St Michael's Primary School on the island. I have had the honour of meeting and being with Sister Geraldine; she has been at the cutting edge of indigenous education on Palm Island for some five years now. I was speaking to her just yesterday and she was telling me quite frankly that Palm Island, sadly, has averaged one suicide a week over the last two months. She sat with the families and attended the funerals. The most worrying part of it is that the people committing suicide are aged between 17 and 25. Some of those people have Thursday, 23 May 1996 MAIN COMMITIEE MC 1333 children of their own. Of the 4,500 people who live on Palm Island, 50 per cent are under the age of 25. In Palm Island's case, when we talk about education outcomes we are talking well beyond primary, secondary and tertiary education. We are talking about life and death. I asked Sister Geraldine how important education is to the future of the people on Palm Island. 'Vital' was the simple answer she gave. The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) said in the second reading of this bill thatÂ·the need for quality was clear. Dr Kemp said: . . . social justice concerns require education to provide a basic foundation of opportunity for all people. BeforeI spoke to Sister Geraldine yesterday, she had no idea about the aims or the details of this bill. Yet, when I started to ask her about what areas of indigenous education she thought were of greatest importance, she instantly identified several of the key strategies identified by the honourable minister in his reading of the bill. 'Get the kids while they're young,' she said, 'and, with the direct assistance of parents and the island elders, provide them with a culturally appropriate education and a continuous overdose of self-esteem. In the long run, it will save lives.' Literacy and numeracy are one thing, but we cannot afford to ignore other areas of indigenous education. The development of culturally sensitive curricula on Palm Island has extended to lessons on the environment, the identifying of bush food sources, and the telling of the history and cultural traits of the Palm Island community. Importantly, it has also started to involve education in areas of nutrition. Bad nutrition habits are one of the major sources of the continued health problems suffered by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in this country. If we can start educating people in good nutritional habits at an early stage, then we can greatly avoid many of the health problems we see now in the indigenous population. If we can prevent certain health problems from ever arising, then we will not have to continue pouring money into funding their treatment. A proper diet can prevent many health problems, including diabetes, digestive problems, renal problems, high blood pressure and heart disease. When we talk about education outcomes in relation to this bill, it is not unreasonable to look into such positive areas as this. The problems on Palm Island are many, but education is an area where a real difference can be made. Get the parents involved. They want to be involved. When parents on Palm Island were given the opportunity to contribute to their children's education and have a say in the planning and development of the school's education program, they eagerly took it up. If we want to find out how to develop culturally sensitive educational environments, then we have to involve the parents. In the five years that Sister Geraldine has been at Palm Island, she has seen a marked increase in parental involvement in education, and that is wonderful. Parents have been involved in education surveys to establish what things they think should be included in the school's curriculum, and they have also been closely involved in the planning and development of a new school building extension. This has had a positive effect on the Palm Island children at St Michael's. They can see their parents taking an active interest in their well-being. It has also had a positive effect on the parents in that they feel they are contributing to something very important, and they are. Get indigenous elders involved. That was something else Sister Geraldine continued to stress, because the elders know the history, culture and heritage of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people better than anyone else. Elders are also the highly respected members of the MC 1334 MAIN COMMIITEE Thursday, 23 May 1996 community. Just before ANZAC Day, there was an article in the Townsville press advocating veterans going to schools to talk to kids about their experiences of war-what life was like, the sights, the smells, the sounds, the home front and so on. If we are going to do that, then let us also get indigenous elders involved with indigenous education. That is what this bill is about. Already, justice programs are being applied on Palm Island and trialled elsewhere in Queensland. Aboriginal elders sit down with juvenile offenders and try to instil in them a sense of responsibility and self-respect. On Palm Island such programs are increasingly having positive effects. Give elders the support they need to get involved with education. In Palm Island's case, that support is urgently needed. About 50 per cent of the population of Palm Island is under 25 years of age, as I have already outlined. If Palm Island's elders are not given the necessary support, in a few years their generation will not be around anymore, and that will have a serious consequence for that community. Push to get indigenous people directly involved in education training. That was another point stressed by Dr Kemp and identified by Sister Geraldine. All teachers' aides and ancillary staff at St Michael's are indigenous people. They are the ones who are really teaching the children there. They are the ones who are the full-time role models for the children during the day. In the second reading speech of the bill, Dr Kemp identified the importance of the transition from education to the work force. But there are also other important transition points that cannot be ignored. We need to explore the possibility of introducing a preparatory year for all students, particularly those in remote centres, who are making the transition from primary to secondary school. In the great majority of cases in distant rural and remote parts of Australia, secondary education means travel to major regional centres. This involves separation from family and friends, boarding school and, in effect, an entire new way of life. This is definitely the case on Palm Island. In 1995, all students from Palm Island entering secondary schools had to be placed in mainland boarding schools. Four have already dropped out. They dropped out, not because they did not want to go to school, but because they were not able to handle the dramatic adjustment in lifestyle. In some cases, children in remote centres are just not ready for mainland high schools and the change in the structure of education that they come across. Primary school indigenous students have three times the literacy and numeracy problems of other students. Twenty-five per cent of indigenous students do not complete year 10. These figures can be improved by providing culturally sensitive educational environments. I believe they can be improved' by easing children of all backgrounds into high school and introducing them to that environment only when they are ready. We have preschool to introduce kids to the idea of going to school and, in certain countries, preparatory years before entering university. For many children in remote Australian communities, both indigenous and non-indigenous, a preparatory year could prove vital in making the transition to a different way of life. Having inherited the economic legacy of the ALP, the need for strict application and distribution of Commonwealth funds is more important than ever. The Australian public, both indigenous and non-indigenous, not unreasonably expect value from their taxes. A more accountable process for the distribution of funds will help to ensure that money goes to those areas where it is most needed. Greater accountability requires better planning of how funds will be spent. It also requires better consultation between politicians, the department, the Thursday, 23 May 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1335 educators and the parents. We should be encouraging schools to develop needs analysis programs in consultation with indigenous parents. That is what this amendment bill is, in part, well and truly addressing. These amendments will, through the restructuring of the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program, contribute to ensuring that such improvements are achieved in indigenous education. I am particularly proud that this bill is outcomes oriented. For the sake of my electorate and the sake of indigenous people in the whole of this nation, I certainly commend this bill to the House. another commitment made during the election campaign. It is not the first time, and it certainly will not be the last time, we will be making good an election promise. Nonetheless, we who are committed to justice for Australia's indigenous peoples believe it to be an important promise. During the life of this government, it is imperative that we address some of the concerns and issues confronting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. The land rights issue continues to dominate the indigenous politics debate-but it is not the whole story. If indigenous people are to enjoy their full and rightful share of this nation's blessings, we must ensure improvements in at least two other fundamental areas. Of these, health is perhaps the most publicised concern; but it is certainly not my intention to broach that issue today. The other is education. This parliament is not the first to recognise the need for action in this all-important area. Indeed, the act we seek to amend was first passed in 1989. In the seven years since it was introduced, the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy has been a qualified success. For the most part, it has received bipartisan backing and has been overseen jointly by the Commonwealth, states and territories. It has produced considerable improvements in both education and training participation for indigenous people. However, there is still a long way to go. The national review of education for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples shows the need for new approaches and increased joint efforts if we are to see our indigenous people achieve educational parity with non-indigenes over the next four yearswhich, incidentally, was the goal set by the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs in December 1995. As with every goal set, there is a preferred route to travel. In this case, the determined course is a series of national priorities for the three years of the Aboriginal education policy, beginning in 1997. There has been agreement amongst indigenous people, the Commonwealth, state and territory governments and education providers that these priorities are critical to the achievement of their goal. The priorities are wide ranging and include the development of career structures for indigenous education workers and a rise in levels of parental involvement in their children's education. Having received a very good education myself, I recognise these two components as all important. It is very difficult for educational authorities to plan and to provide the best when there is a cloud hanging over their future. Like almost all Australians, they want and need security when making plans for the future, and it is gratifying to see that this need has been recognised. This bill guarantees funding through to the tum of the century, and that will be welcome news for the education providers.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Pyne (Sturt) (10.57 A.m.)
theText: In seeking the passage of this bill, the coalition is honouringMC 1336 MAIN COMMITIEE Thursday, 23 May 1996 I welcome, too, the move to involve parents in the education process. Teachers conly do so much, and a real love of learning can be instilled by a child's parents, who can encourage creativity in their children long after the formal lessons are over. Parents are very often responsible for instilling a love of learning in their children at a very early age-at the very least, the greater their interest, the greater the child's. Another of the defined priorities is the need for indigenous children to attend preschool education programs. The national experience has shown that children who attend kindergarten or other preschool programs have a significant head start on those who do not. The forced separation of Aboriginal families over the years has led to a decline in the use of their own languages. I am very happy to see that the program will offer encouragement for students to study indigenous languages, which are very much part of their heritage and their culture. We have had hundreds of government programs in these past 20 years attempting to fix one situation or another. Some programs have been a downright failure, particularly those where governments have simply thrown money -at a problem. This we will not do. However, it is a necessary element of an election promise that this is funded fully. This government plans to do just that. Over the next four years, we will be more than doubling expenditure on this program. In all, nearly $180 million has been earmarked for supplementary assistance to the education of indigenous Australians. With this increase in assistance will come increased accountability. The funding structure of the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program will change. From January next year, . AESIP resources will be distributed to eligible providers on a per capita basis. This is not to say that providers will be worse off than they are today. For the first year, at least, funding minimums will be set at the current rate. But per capita spending is, in the longer term, an inducement to increase participation rates. Under the new arrangements, each eligible provider will negotiate an indigenous education agreement that identifies specific targets to improve performance in one or more areas deemed a priority. Current performance levels will be the point from which potential improvements are targeted and measured. The per capita funding should enable providers-whether they be Commonwealth, state, territory or otherwise-to address the high costs of education in remote areas and the many disadvantages experienced by indigenous students. With these agreements signed, the Commonwealth will be in,terested in participation rates and, obviously, results. The methods will be of the providers' choosing and, given the diversity of situations, I am sure that providers will go about their tasks in different ways. The annual performance reviews will judge if they have been successful in achieving their defined targets. In addition to the per capita spending, this bill also provides for the strategic results projects. These funds, which represent only a fraction of the total expenditures, will be allocated toward researching and implementing measures that will improve results across the education sector. Universities will be eligible to participate in these projects. This bill will improve the chances of indigenous people participating in and receiving a better education. An education has always been vital, never more so than it is today. Many of life's options are decided for us by the standard of education we are offered and whether we take up that offer. I believe this bill offers both opportunity and encouragement. I commend it to the House. Thursday, 23 May 1996 MAIN COMMI1TEE MC 1337 Education, Training and Youth Affairs) (11.00 a.m.)-I am very pleased to be able to sum up and conclude this debate on behalf of the government. This is a bill which keeps one of our pre-election commitments to spend an additional $143 million on Aboriginal education, and it is one pre-election commitment that obviously the government is extremely happy to keep. I take the poitlt of the member for Aston( Mr Nugent) that Aboriginal education depends on many things apart from simply educational funding. It depends upon good health and good housing, but education is what we are addressing today, and I am delighted to have the member for Aston's support. One of the glories of our nation is the tremendous efforts that have been made over the last 20 or 30 years to bring our Aboriginal people into full communion with the rest of our society. A sign of success, amidst all the gloom and doom we so often hear on this general subject, is that Aboriginal retention rates, while not good enough, while nowhere near retention rates for the wider community, are now at least at levels which would have been regarded as quite acceptable for the wider community just 15 years ago. It is sad that Aboriginal year 12 retention rates are only 30 per cent, but let us remember that this is where they all were just 15 years ago. I take also the point of the member for the Northern Territory ( Mr Dondas) about the importance of education in English. I recall a story that was once told by our friend and colleague the member for Kalgoorlie ( Mr Campbell) of a visit to a remote Aboriginal outstation by the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand. The minister came to the out-station' and he sat down and made a lengthy speech-in English, of course--explaining to the elders how important it was that their kids were educated in their Aboriginal languages. At the end of the minister's long speech, the elders stood up and said, 'Minister, are you aware of the Pitjantjatjara word for helicopter?' The minister said, 'Well, I'm sorry, I'm not.' They said, 'The Pitjantjatjara word for helicopter is helicopter, and, if you don't educate our kids in English, how on earth are our kids ever going to get on, and how on earth are they ever going to compete in the wider society?' SoI very much take the member for the Northern Territory's point; it was well made. The member for the Northern Territory also referred to what he says is a $3 million drop in funding that the territory will suffer under this bill. I want to point out that that statement is predicated upon transitional arrangements which have yet to be finalised. I am very confident that the territory government will have a strong ally in the member for the Northern Territory in negotiating the best possible deal for the territory. I also take the point that the member for the Northern Territory made that education in remote areas is vastly more expensive than education in urban centres such as Katherine, Alice Springs and Darwin. But I want to point out to the member that there are additional programs that will at least go part of the way to accommodating the problems that he so rightly refers to. This bill is establishing the principle of per capita funding in Aboriginal education. Essentially, per capita funding means that if you have the students you get the money. In other words, this is the best possible way to ensure that educational institutions are doing the right thing by their clients. Until now, funding has depended upon an annual negotiation. The trouble with annual negotiations is that you are never quite sure exactly how much money you
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Abbott (Warringah
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment,MC 1338 MAIN COMMITIEE Thursday, 23 May 1996 are going to get from one year to the next, and you are never quite sure whether-this year, next year or the year after-your mates or someone else's mates are going to find themselves in positions of authority on the distributing panel. By moving to per capita funding we are establishing more transparency in the funding of Aboriginal education, and that is something which I think everyone in this House would applaud. As my friend and colleague the member for Sturt( Mr Pyne) pointed out, this bill also provides for performance reviews so that the providers of Aboriginal education should be subject to the same kinds of standards and performance testing which we expect of everyone else. The thing which always impresses me, Madam Deputy Speaker, whenever Aboriginal issues are debated in this parliament, is the care and the compassion which every member of the parliament brings to the subject. On this subject. I want to say how delighted I am that Senator John Herron is the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. John Herron is a man of extraordinary integrity and great compassion. He is a great Australian. John Herron is the kind of person who could very well end up giving politicians a good name. When discussing Aboriginal subjects, I am always somewhat reminded of the words of Ken Slessor in his famous poem, Beach Burial. He was writing about a different subject; nevertheless, I think the words are apt: And each cross, the driven stake of tidewood, Bears the last signature of men, Written with such perplexity, with such bewildered pity, The words choke as they beginWe have struggled to come to grips with this issue-we have struggled for 208 years to come to grips with this issue-but we are getting there. When we do manage to bring about complete reconciliation, or reconciliation as complete as is humanly possible, between black and white Australians, it will be to the great glory of our nation and it will be one of the greatest days, if not the greatest day, in Australia's history. The way to do that is to remember that the things that unite us are always more important than the things that divide us. We white Australians have a lot more in common with black Australians than the newspapers would sometimes give credit for. Aboriginals' cultural memory extends back 40,000 years-and which of us white Australians can say that? They have had the stewardship of our nation for all but the last 200 years, and they will always have great honour for that. But the important thing to recall is that the average black Australian, like the average white Australian, wants to get ahead, wants a better deal for himself or herself, and in particular wants a better deal for his or her children. As my friend Charlie Perkins memorably said, 'We have got to get off our black butts, too'. That is something that is well remembered whenever we are discussing this subject. I would like to conclude by pointing to something which I think is a very welcome development. A lot of my friends and colleagues have been most disconcerted by some of the things that have happened with ATSIC recently and some of the controversy surrounding the Hindmarsh Island Bridge. They have worried that these controversies have brought Aboriginal Australians into disrepute. That is one way of looking at it-and certainly there have been some bad headlines over the last 12 months. But another way of looking at it is that there is now a new pluralism in Aboriginal politics. We now have Aboriginal people, on both sides of Aboriginal issues, standing up and speaking for themselves. It was not, as it happened, white fellows who raised some of the problems with the Hindmarsh Island Bridge; it was the Thursday, 23 May 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1339 dissident Ngarrindjeri women. It was not, in fact, white fellows who raised some of the problems with ATSIC; it was people like Sharon Firebrace, Peter Yu and others, who were standing up and saying, 'We, the Aboriginal people, have got to be judged by the same standards of fairness and honesty by which everyone else is judged, and we have got to abide by the same standards of fairness and honesty which we expect to be delivered to us.' I think what has become apparent over the last 12 months or so is that some of the people whom we are accustomed to go to as spokesmen or spokeswomen for the Aboriginal people no more represent Aboriginal people than, say, the Liberal Party or the Labor Party represents the Australian people. Often we do speak for the whole of the Australian people, but more often we do not. Occasionally there is a transcendent moment when the representative of one party or one party can speak for the whole of the people. But mostly it does not happen, and one party is simply speaking for a faction, or indeed a fraction, of the Australian people. And so it is now with Aboriginal affairs as well. In conclusion, I want to indicate the government's strong intention to continue speaking to everyone in this debate-not just the people who agree with us, not just the people who disagree with us, but everyone. That is the only way that we are going to do justice to all Australians. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Bill-by leave-reported to the House without amendment. Consideration resumed from 9 May. Second Reading Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games) (11.11 a.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this bill is to amend the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989 to ensure that Australia can discharge its obligations under international instruments relating to the control of transboundary movements of hazardous waste. The principal act was passed at the time that the Basel convention was negotiated and in the chamber of December 1989. By coincidence, I actually took the bill through the House on that occasion on behalf of the then opposition. At that time the major concern regarding trade in hazardous waste related to hazardous waste sent to another country for what is termed final disposal, that is, for incineration, landfilling or the like. As a result, the principal act defines waste as material which has been rejected as worthless or otherwise falls within the ordinary definition of waste. As such it generally does not cover material sent for recovery. In the years since the convention was negotiated the emphasis in international debate has shifted to its coverage of materials which are traded for recovery operations, that is, for reclamation of metals or recovery of other useful materials.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Warwick Smith (Bass
theText: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government andMC 1340 MAIN COMMITIEE Thursday, 23 May 1996 Just as the trade in hazardous waste for final disposal led to an active process of transferring the environmental costs associated with the generation of hazardous waste from one country to another, and in particular from developed to developing countries, so the trade in hazardous waste for recovery operations can similarly lead to the transfer of environmental costs in an uncontrolled fashion. The Basel convention was drafted to cover both kinds of processes, that is, both final disposal and recovery operations, and both kinds of processes are included in the convention definitions under the single term 'disposal-. The Australian act does not cover a wide range of hazardous wastes from which valuable materials are to be recovered; these hazardous wastes have not been rejected as worthless or do not fall within the ordinary meaning of waste. The major purpose of amending the act is to remedy this discrepancy between our international obligations and our domestic legislation. The Basel convention is the primary international instrument under which trade in hazardous waste is controlled and, as I said, in 1989 we endorsed that. It is the set of rules for this trade on which Australia and the many other countries which are parties to the convention have agreed. As virtually all of Australia's trading partners are either parties to the convention or parties to similar sets of rules established by the OECD, it is in Australia's trade interests, as well as within our international obligations, to abide by these rules. The interpretation of the convention as expressed in the principal act and with the amendments now put forward is in line with the views of other parties to the convention. In the absence of these amendments, Australia will continue to be out of step with other parties in its capacity to give domestic effect to the convention. In accordance with the primary intention of the bill, the object of the act is to be amended to make it clear that one of its major aims is to give domestic effect to the Basel convention and other international instruments relating to trade in hazardous wastes. The definition of hazardous waste, now to be adopted, is aligned with that in the convention. This will ensure that in future Australia does not find itself in breach of the convention by virtue of having adopted a definition which is at odds with the interpretation of the convention followed by others. Nevertheless, the question of definition remains central to the operation of the act and, indeed, definitional questions remain the subject of very active debate in Basel convention meetings. In Australia a higher degree of concern has been expressed because of the uncertainty of the definitions in the convention. The bill addresses these concerns through the establishment of a process to provide greater practical certainty regarding what is and is not a hazardous waste. The bill provides for the establishment of a technical group of scientific and technical experts who will advise the minister on definitional questions. The advice of this group will be of great benefit in enabling the ininister to decide whether he or she believes that a material falls within the definition of hazardous waste and so is regulated. The minister will have the power to issue evidentiary certificates which will be prima facie evidence that a given material is or is not a hazardous waste. Also, by compiling a list of materials for which evidentiary certificates have been issued the minister will be able to provide greater certainty to those subject to regulation on what materials will be controlled and what will not. This means, for example, that it will be possible to issue an evidentiary certificate stating that a material such as clean ferrous scrap is not a hazardous waste subject to the act and that Thursday, 23 May 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 1341 it can be traded without any controls. At the same time, flexibility will be retained to respond to incremental progress in international discussions on what materials should and should not be controlled. As an example, recent international discussions suggest that the existence of internationally recognised product specifications will be influential in deciding what are and are not hazardous wastes. The evidentiary certificates will not be conclusive but will be prima facie evidence and the definitions in the act would remain as the final means of determining the definitional question. In practice, the advice of the technical group will provide the government with the capability of issuing clear guidance on definitional issues and should satisfy the needs of those who are subject to regulation for a clear understanding of their obligations under the act. There are many who would prefer to replace the uncertain Basel definitions with Australia's own list or set of criteria. To follow that course, however, would inevitably lead to Australia once again being at odds with the convention and the views of our trading partners on what constitutes hazardous waste under the convention. This would risk not only a breach of our international obligations but could well lead to shipments acceptable under our definitions being rejected at foreign ports to the embarrassment, cost and inconvenience of all. The convention itself recognises that the hazard criteria it establishes are in need of further development. There is provision for the development of national tests which would provide greater precision in detennining whether a waste is hazardous. That provision is included in the relevant annex to the convention by reference to which the bill defines hazardous waste. Over time the technical group will advise on national tests to establish hazard on a more certain basis, taking account of international developments. Another key concept in the convention now adopted into the act is the definition of 'environmentally sound management'. The convention requires not only that an exporting country obtain prior consent from the country of import before allowing the transboundary movement to proceed, but also that the country of export requires that the waste to be shipped is managed in an environmentally sound way in the country of import. The concept of environmentally sound management of hazardous waste is defined in the convention as taking all practicable steps to ensure that the hazardous waste is managed to protect human health and the environment. The technical group will advise the minister to assist in the detennination of what constitutes environmentally sound management and whether particular facilities or processes meet the definition. For that reason it will include people with expertise in scientific and technical, social and economic, environmental and public health fields. The concept of environmentally sound management as set out in the convention replaces the phrase in the principal act, 'dispose of safely'. In the principal act, 'dispose of safely' is defined in terms of an outcome, that is, that hazardous waste is disposed of safely provided there is no damage to human health or the environment. By contrast, 'environmentally sound management' is defined now by reference to a process, that is, taking all practicable steps to prevent damage to human health and the environment. On the other hand, the definition of 'dispose of safely' appears to exclude any assessment of effluents and emissions from the disposal process. In practice, pragmatic considerations are likely to prevail. Within the Basel convention process detailed guidelines on what constitutes environmentally sound management have already been drafted and these will provide the context of the technical group's advice to the MC 1342 MAIN COMMITIEE Thursday, 23 May 1996 minister. Australia will put its efforts into ensuring that those guidelines are sound. Once again the need to ensure that our legislation is fully in line with our international obligations is the overriding consideration in the changes set out in the bill. Under the convention, the general rule is that parties must not trade in hazardous waste with non-parties. An exception to this is provided for in article 11, whereby parties may enter into agreements or arrangements either with other parties or with non-parties. These agreements or arrangements can set out controls which are different from those prescribed by the convention itself, provided those controls do not reduce the level of environment protection intended by the convention. The main such agreement to which Australia is a party is the OECD decision on transboundary movements of hazardous waste destined for recovery operations which regulates transboundary movements of hazardous wastes among OECD countries. The bill provides explicitly for regulations giving effect to such agreements and arrangements and for those regulations to give domestic effect to rules different from those in the convention. The materials covered by the agreements or arrangements may also differ to some extent from those covered by the convention, thus the OECD decision covers some wastes which are not hazardous wastes under the convention and trade in these must comply with the controls set oQt by the decision. Conversely, the decision classifies some materials as nonhazardous wastes, known as the OECD green list, and these materials may be traded without a pennit provided countries outside the OECD are not involved. The provisions are general and can be applied to any further article 11 agreements or arrangements which Australia enters into. The procedures by which the minister reaches a decision on whether or not a permit should be issued for a transboundary movement have been amended once again to bring the act more closely into line with the convention. Among the changes are those ensuring that the notification and consent procedures established by the convention are followed. Another amends the existing provision that the minister have regard to the prospect of processing hazardous waste within Australia rather than allowing export to take place. This is in accordance with article 4(2)(d) of the convention which requires parties to 'minimise the transboundary movement of hazardous waste consistent with the environmentally sound and efficient management of hazardous waste.' The intent of this article is met by requirements that disposal in Australia must be efficient, safe and environmentally sound. The intent is that a local disposal facility must be more than merely an experimental or test facility and must operate on a commercial basis. There must be some cost-effectiveness factor which is brought to bear when the minister weighs up the pros and cons of local versus overseas disposal in deciding whether or not a permit should be issued. The principal act already provides th-t there must be appropriate insurance for shipments of hazardous waste before a permit is issued. A new provision in the bill allows the minister to require bonds or guarantees in addition to or instead of insurance. This recognises that where there is contravention of a permit for one reason or other, an insurance policy may not be paid out and in an appropriate case a bond would allow the Commonwealth to ensure that there was some coverage. In other cases insurance may not be available and a guarantee would provide the opportunity for a permit to be issued in such cases. The principal act allows the sum total of such arrangements-insurance bonds and guarantees-to be assessed when the minister comes to a decision. Thursday, 23 May 1996 MAIN COMMITIEE MC 1343 Other procedural amendments are aimed at ensuring that the administration of the act proceeds smoothly and efficiently and that all convention requirements are met. Because the convention itself contains detailed rules, it has not been possible to simplify the administrative system beyond a certain point. That is why both the principal act and the amending bill are complex. Where possible and appropriate, provision is made for the making of regulations to set out requirements under the act in order to ensure that its administration will be flexible and responsive to the needs of industry. A detailed set of administrative procedures is being developed in consultation with interested parties, including industry, and will be completed by the time the amendments are ready to come into force. The act also addresses a number of aspects of the convention which were not picked up in the original drafting process. One of the most important of these is the issue of transit permits-that is, for Australian consent or its denial to the transiting of waste from another country on its way to a third country for disposal. There is also explicit provision for more than one shipment of the same hazardous waste to be covered by a single permit. The convention allows such a procedure up to a maximum of 12 months provided that certain conditions are met and that is now reflected in the bill. The current system for recovery of the government's administrative costs in respect of issuing permits is unnecessarily inflexible. The bill provides for fees to be set in regulations on the basis of administrative costs of each type of permit. The minister has discretion to reduce these where appropriate. The fee level may not be above the fee currently prescribed in the principal act. Penalties under the act have increased in order to provide a deterrent to illegal traffic. Prevention of illegal traffic is specifically required by the convention and the value of some of the transactions involved requires that penalties be raised to ensure that companies are deterred from failing to comply with the act's requirements. A new provision is that executive officers of companies will be personally liable for contraventions by companies with the onus of proof resting with the Commonwealth. That is, liability will not be automatic. Liability for executive officers of companies is an important step in ensuring compliance with the act, as it would be difficult for other compliance measures to be effective. For example, identification of hazardous waste at customs barriers when materials leave the country would often be difficult given that hazardous waste cannot readily be distinguished from a variety of other materials. Third party standing under the principal act is already very broad with respect to appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Standing under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, known as the ADJR Act, has been extended by providing standing for Australian organisations and associations which have matters which relate to the act as part of their object or purpose. This section is intended to extend but not limit the existing standing provisions which are provided under the ADJR Act. This will provide further legislative clarity to the standing rules for the purposes of the ADJR Act and as an extension of the standing rules already recognised in recent cases under other similar legislation.
